expanded_description: This section focuses on adding vectors that are perpendicular to each other. When two vectors are at right angles, their resultant can be found using the Pythagorean theorem for magnitude and simple trigonometry for direction. This special case is common in physics, especially when dealing with horizontal and vertical components of motion.

core_concept.principle: When two vectors are perpendicular, the magnitude of their resultant is found using the Pythagorean theorem: $R = \sqrt{A^2 + B^2}$, and the direction is given by $\theta = \tan^{-1}(B/A)$ (or $A/B$) relative to one of the vectors.
core_concept.explanation: Perpendicular vectors are independent; their effects do not interfere. The resultant is the diagonal of the rectangle (or square) formed by the two vectors. This simplicity makes perpendicular vector addition a cornerstone of two‑dimensional kinematics, especially for resolving motion into horizontal and vertical components.

sections.introduction: When two vectors are at right angles (90°) to each other, their addition is particularly straightforward. This situation appears frequently in physics, for example when combining horizontal and vertical velocity components or when adding force vectors that are perpendicular.

key_concept.definition: Perpendicular vector addition is the process of finding the resultant of two vectors that are oriented at 90° to each other. The resultant's magnitude is given by the Pythagorean theorem, and its direction is found using an inverse tangent.
key_concept.context: Understanding this special case is essential because any vector can be broken into perpendicular components; adding those components back together is exactly the reverse of resolution.

principles.statement: If $\vec{A}$ and $\vec{B}$ are perpendicular, the magnitude of their resultant $\vec{R} = \vec{A} + \vec{B}$ is $R = \sqrt{A^2 + B^2}$.
principles.application: Treat the two vectors as the legs of a right triangle; the resultant is the hypotenuse.
principles.example: A displacement of 3 km east and 4 km north gives $R = \sqrt{3^2 + 4^2} = 5$ km.

principles.statement: The direction of the resultant relative to $\vec{A}$ is given by $\theta = \tan^{-1}(B/A)$, where $B$ is the magnitude of the vector perpendicular to $A$.
principles.application: Choose a reference vector and use the appropriate ratio. The angle tells how far the resultant is rotated from that reference.
principles.example: For the 3 km east and 4 km north vectors, the angle north of east is $\theta = \tan^{-1}(4/3) = 53.1°$.

principles.statement: Graphically, the two perpendicular vectors form a rectangle (or square if equal). The resultant is the diagonal from the origin to the opposite corner.
principles.application: This visual helps verify calculations and understand that the resultant is always longer than either individual vector (unless one is zero).
principles.example: Drawing a 3 cm arrow east and a 4 cm arrow north tip‑to‑tail shows the 5 cm diagonal.

worked_examples.title: Basic Perpendicular Addition
worked_examples.problem: A car travels 6.0 km east, then 8.0 km north. Find the displacement (magnitude and direction) from the starting point.

step_by_step.explanation: $\vec{A} = 6.0$ km east, $\vec{B} = 8.0$ km north. They are perpendicular.

worked_examples.concept_applied: For perpendicular vectors, magnitude uses Pythagorean theorem, direction uses arctan of the ratio.

worked_examples.title: Perpendicular Vectors with Different Units
worked_examples.problem: A force of 12 N acts horizontally to the right, and a force of 5 N acts vertically upward. Find the resultant force.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Same method applies to any vector quantities (force, velocity, displacement).

worked_examples.title: Resultant When One Vector is Zero
worked_examples.problem: A boat travels 10 m/s east, and there is no current (0 m/s north). Find the resultant velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: $v_x = 10$ m/s, $v_y = 0$ m/s. They are still perpendicular (zero vector is perpendicular to any vector).

worked_examples.concept_applied: Adding a zero vector leaves the other unchanged.

image.caption: The resultant of perpendicular vectors forms the hypotenuse of a right triangle

sections.introduction: When several vectors are all mutually perpendicular (e.g., along x, y, and possibly z axes), the resultant can be found by first summing components in each direction, then applying the Pythagorean theorem (in 2D) or its extension (in 3D).

key_concept.definition: For multiple perpendicular vectors, combine all vectors along the same direction into a single component, then treat the resulting perpendicular components as a new pair.
key_concept.context: This approach is essentially the component method simplified because the vectors are already aligned with the axes.

principles.statement: Add all vectors pointing in the same direction to get a net component along that axis.
principles.application: If you have several east vectors and several west vectors, find the net east component (taking signs into account). Do the same for north/south.
principles.example: 5 N east + 3 N east + 2 N west = (5+3-2) = 6 N east.

principles.statement: Once you have one net horizontal component and one net vertical component (they are perpendicular), use the Pythagorean theorem and arctan to find the resultant.
principles.application: Treat the net components as the legs of a right triangle.
principles.example: If net east = 6 N and net north = 8 N, then $R = 10$ N at $\theta = \tan^{-1}(8/6)$.

worked_examples.title: Multiple Perpendicular Vectors
worked_examples.problem: An object experiences forces: 10 N east, 7 N east, 4 N west, 5 N north, and 2 N south. Find the net force.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Combine like directions first, then treat the two perpendicular components as a single pair.

sections.introduction: Adding perpendicular vectors is exactly the reverse process of resolving a vector into components. Understanding this connection solidifies the concept.

key_concept.definition: If a vector $\vec{R}$ has components $R_x$ and $R_y$, then $\vec{R}$ is the resultant of the perpendicular vectors $R_x\hat{i}$ and $R_y\hat{j}$.
key_concept.context: This relationship shows that component resolution and perpendicular addition are two sides of the same coin.

principles.statement: Any vector can be thought of as the sum of two perpendicular vectors (its components).
principles.application: When you have the components, you already have the perpendicular vectors; adding them gives back the original vector.
principles.example: A vector with components 3 and 4 is the sum of a 3‑unit horizontal vector and a 4‑unit vertical vector.

summary: Adding perpendicular vectors is a fundamental skill in 2D kinematics. When two vectors are at right angles, the magnitude of their resultant is given by the Pythagorean theorem: $R = \sqrt{A^2 + B^2}$, where $A$ and $B$ are the magnitudes of the perpendicular vectors. The direction of the resultant relative to one of the vectors is found using the inverse tangent: $\theta = \tan^{-1}(\text{opposite}/\text{adjacent})$. This method extends to multiple perpendicular vectors by first combining all vectors along the same axis to obtain net components, then treating those net components as a perpendicular pair. The process is the reverse of resolving a vector into components: if a vector has components $R_x$ and $R_y$, it is the resultant of perpendicular vectors of those magnitudes. Common mistakes include incorrectly adding magnitudes (using $A+B$ instead of the Pythagorean sum), mixing up the ratio for the angle, and neglecting the signs of components when determining the quadrant for the direction. Mastery of perpendicular vector addition prepares students for more general vector addition and for analyzing projectile motion, where horizontal and vertical motions are perpendicular and independent.
